qas.question: Who invaded Britain when the Romans Left

answers.text: Britain was invaded by Anglo-Saxon peoples

qas.question: It took how long for the Anglo Saxons to control  the Somerset area

answers.text: by the early eighth century King Ine of Wessex had pushed the boundaries of the West Saxon kingdom far enough west to include Somerset

qas.question: What was the Saxon Royal Palace used for

answers.text: was used several times in the 10th century to host the Witenagemot

qas.question: What prison does somerset county contain

answers.text: HM Prison Shepton Mallet, which was England's oldest prison still in use prior to its closure in 2013, having opened in 1610

qas.question: What rebellion took place in Somerset in 1685

answers.text: Monmouth Rebellion was played out in Somerset and neighbouring Dorset

qas.question: In what year did the Romans leave Britain?
In what year did King Ine of Wessex rise to power?
In what century did the Norman Conquest occur?
In what year did the Sieges of Taunton occur?
Who led the forces against the rebels in the Monmouth Rebellion?

context: After the Romans left, <a0_0>Britain was invaded by Anglo-Saxon peoples<a0_0/>. By <b5_0><b6_0>AD 600<b6_0/><b5_0/> they had established control over much of what is now England, but Somerset was still in native British hands. The British held back Saxon advance into the south-west for some time longer, but <a1_0>by the early eighth century <b9_0>King Ine of Wessex<b9_0/> had pushed the boundaries of the West Saxon kingdom far enough west to include Somerset<a1_0/>. The Saxon royal palace in Cheddar <a2_0>was used several times in the <b7_0>10th century<b7_0/> to host the Witenagemot<a2_0/>. After the Norman Conquest, the county was divided into 700 fiefs, and large areas were owned by the crown, with fortifications such as Dunster Castle used for control and defence. Somerset contains <a3_0>HM Prison Shepton Mallet, which was England's oldest prison still in use prior to its closure in 2013, having opened in <b8_0>1610<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In the English Civil War Somerset was largely Parliamentarian, with key engagements being the Sieges of Taunton and the Battle of Langport. In 1685 the <a4_0>Monmouth Rebellion was played out in Somerset and neighbouring Dorset<a4_0/>. The rebels landed at Lyme Regis and travelled north, hoping to capture Bristol and Bath, but they were defeated in the Battle of Sedgemoor at Westonzoyland, the last pitched battle fought in England. Arthur Wellesley took his title, Duke of Wellington from the town of Wellington; he is commemorated on a nearby hill by a large, spotlit obelisk, known as the Wellington Monument.
